title: Photography History
description: Journey through the fascinating history of photography, from daguerreotypes to digital cameras!

questions.question: Who is credited with creating the first permanent photograph in 1826 or 1827?
questions.explanation: Niépce created 'View from the Window at Le Gras' using a process called heliography. The exposure reportedly took several hours or possibly days to complete.

questions.question: What was the daguerreotype, introduced in 1839?
options: An early photographic process using silver-coated copper plates
questions.explanation: Louis Daguerre developed the daguerreotype process, which produced a unique image on a polished silver-coated copper plate. It was the first commercially practical photographic process.

questions.question: Which company founder popularized photography with the slogan 'You press the button, we do the rest'?
questions.explanation: George Eastman founded Kodak in 1888 and introduced the first simple, affordable camera. His slogan reflected the ease of use — customers sent the entire camera back to Kodak for developing.

questions.question: Ansel Adams is best known for his stunning black-and-white photographs of what subject?
options: The American West and national parks
questions.explanation: Ansel Adams captured majestic landscapes of Yosemite, the Sierra Nevada, and other American wilderness areas. He also co-developed the 'Zone System' for precise exposure control.

questions.question: What does the term 'photography' literally mean, from its Greek roots?
questions.explanation: The word 'photography' comes from Greek 'photos' (light) and 'graphe' (drawing or writing). It was first used by scientist Sir John Herschel in 1839.

questions.question: Which photographer documented the horrors of the American Civil War?
questions.explanation: Mathew Brady and his team of photographers captured thousands of images during the Civil War, bringing the reality of warfare to the public for the first time through photography.

questions.question: Edwin Land's company Polaroid introduced what revolutionary product in 1948?
questions.explanation: The Polaroid Model 95 was the first instant camera, producing a finished print in about 60 seconds. Land was inspired when his daughter asked why she couldn't see a photo right away.

questions.question: Dorothea Lange's iconic 1936 photograph 'Migrant Mother' documented what era?
questions.explanation: Lange photographed Florence Owens Thompson and her children at a pea-pickers' camp in California. The image became the defining photograph of the Great Depression.

questions.question: What innovation by Oskar Barnack led to the creation of the Leica camera in the 1920s?
options: Using 35mm movie film for still photography
questions.explanation: Oskar Barnack adapted 35mm cinema film for use in a compact still camera, creating the Leica I. This revolutionized photography by making cameras small and portable enough for street photography.

questions.question: Which photographer is known for his 'decisive moment' philosophy of capturing spontaneous events?
questions.explanation: Henri Cartier-Bresson coined the concept of 'the decisive moment' — capturing an event at the precise instant that is most revealing. He co-founded the Magnum Photos agency in 1947.

questions.question: When was the first commercially available digital camera sold to consumers?
questions.explanation: While Kodak engineer Steven Sasson built a prototype digital camera in 1975, the first consumer digital cameras appeared around 1990, including the Dycam Model 1 (also sold as the Logitech Fotoman).

questions.question: What type of photography did Edward Weston and Imogen Cunningham pioneer with their sharp, detailed images?
questions.explanation: Straight photography emphasized sharp focus, full tonal range, and precise composition without manipulation. Weston and Cunningham were founding members of Group f/64, named after a small aperture setting.

questions.question: The famous 'Earthrise' photograph, showing Earth from the Moon, was taken during which mission?
questions.explanation: Astronaut William Anders took the 'Earthrise' photo on December 24, 1968 during the Apollo 8 mission. It was one of the first color photos of Earth from space and became an icon of the environmental movement.

questions.question: What does SLR stand for in camera terminology?
questions.explanation: SLR stands for Single Lens Reflex. These cameras use a mirror and prism system so the photographer sees through the same lens that takes the picture, ensuring accurate framing.

questions.question: Which photographer was known for powerful portraits of working-class Americans, including 'American Gothic' parodies?
questions.explanation: Walker Evans documented American life during the Great Depression for the Farm Security Administration. His book 'American Photographs' (1938) is considered one of the most influential photography books ever published.
